Wedderburn decomposition
a list of simple algebras as GAP objects
Computes the list of Wedderburn components of a group algebra FG realizable by strongly Shoda pairs of G. The input FG should be a group ring over a finite group G with coefficients in F, where F is either the field Q of rationals or a inite field whose characteristic is coprime with the order of G.
For many groups G every Wedderburn component of FG is realizable by a strongly Shoda pair and then the direct product of the entries of the output is isomorphic to FG. For example these is the case if G is abelian-by-supersolvable .
gap> FD16:=GroupRing(GF(5),DihedralGroup(16)); <algebra-with-one over GF(5), with 4 generators> gap> WedderburnDecomposition(FD16); [ GF(5), GF(5), GF(5), GF(5), ( GF(5)^[ 2, 2 ] ), ( GF(5^2)^[ 2, 2 ] ) ]
The previous example shows that the Wedderburn decomposition of the group algebra GF(5)D_{16} of the dihedral group of order 16 over the field of order 5 is 4GF(5) \oplus M_2(GF(5)) \oplus M_2(GF(25)).
Next example shows the Wedderburn decomposition of the rational group algebra of the symmetric group on 4 letters.
gap> QS4:=GroupRing(Rationals,SymmetricGroup(4)); <algebra-with-one over Rationals, with 2 generators> gap> WedderburnDecomposition(QS4); [ Rationals, Rationals, ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), <crossed product over CF(3), with 2 generators> ]
If not all the Wedderburn components of the input are realizable by strongly Shoda pairs then a warning message is displayed together with the output.
gap> G:=SmallGroup(24,3);QG:=GroupRing(Rationals,G); <pc group of size 24 with 4 generators> <algebra-with-one over Rationals, with 4 generators> gap> WedderburnDecomposition(QG); Wedderga: Warning!! The direct product of the output is a PROPER direct factor of the input! [ Rationals, CF(3), ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ) ]
a list of descriptions of simple algebras (not as GAP objects)
Computes some numerical data describing the Wedderburn components of a group algebra FG realizable by strongly Shoda pairs of G .
The input FG should be as in .
The interpretation of the information displayed by the output is explained in .
gap> F:=FreeGroup("a","b");;a:=F.1;;b:=F.2;;rel:=[a^8,a^4*b^2,b^-1*a*b*a];; gap> Q16:=F/rel; QQ16:=GroupRing(Rationals,Q16); <fp group on the generators [ a, b ]> <algebra-with-one over Rationals, with 2 generators> gap> QS4:=GroupRing(Rationals,SymmetricGroup(4)); <algebra-with-one over Rationals, with 2 generators> gap> WedderburnDecomposition(QQ16); [ Rationals, Rationals, Rationals, Rationals, ( Rationals^[ 2, 2 ] ), <crossed product over CF(8), with 2 generators> ] gap> WedderburnDecomposition(QS4); [ Rationals, Rationals, ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), <crossed product over CF(3), with 2 generators> ] gap> WedderburnDecompositionInfo(QQ16); [ [ 1, 1, [ ], [ ] ], [ 1, 2, [ ], [ ] ], [ 1, 2, [ ], [ ] ], [ 1, 2, [ ], [ ] ], [ 2, 2, [ ], [ ] ], [ 1, 8, [ [ 2, 7, 4 ] ], [ ] ] ] gap> WedderburnDecompositionInfo(QS4); [ [ 1, 1, [ ], [ ] ], [ 1, 2, [ ], [ ] ], [ 3, 2, [ ], [ ] ], [ 3, 2, [ ], [ ] ], [ 1, 3, [ [ 2, 2, 0 ] ], [ ] ] ]
In the previous example one has computed the Wedderburn decomposition of the rational group algebra QQ16 of the quaternion group of order 16 and the rational group algebra QS4 of the symmetric group in four letters. For both group algebras one has used both and .
The output shows that
QQ16 = 4 \Q \oplus M_2(\Q) \oplus A
QS4 = 2Q \oplus 2 M_2(\Q) \oplus B
where A and B are crossed products with coefficients in the cyclotomic fields CF(8) and CF(3) respectively. This output can be used as a GAP object but as it is it does not give precise information on the algebras A and B.
Instead the numerical information displayed by means that
A = Q(\xi|\xi^8=1)[g | \xi^g = \xi^7 = \xi^{-1}, g^2 = \xi^4 = -1]
B = Q(\xi|\xi^3=1)[g | \xi^g = \xi^2 = \xi^{-1}, g^2 = 1]
Both A and B are quaternion algebras over its centre which is Q(\xi+\xi^{-1}) and the former is equal to Q(\sqrt{2}) and Q respectively.
In B, one has (g+1)(g-1)=0, while g is neither 1 nor -1. This shows that B=M_2(Q). However the relation g^2=-1 in A shows that
A=Q(\sqrt{2})[i,g|i^2=g^2=-1,ig=-gi]
and so A is a division algebra with centre Q(\sqrt{2}), which is a subalgebra of the algebra of Hamiltonian quaternions.

ManSection.Returns: A simple algebra as GAP object
ManSection.Description:
The versions with three input data computes the Wedderburn component of the rational group algebra QG of a finite group G realized by a strongly Shoda pair (K,H) of G (see Section ).
The versions with four input data computes the Wedderburn component of the semisimple finite group algebra FG realized by a strongly Shoda pair (K,H) of G and a generating q-cyclotomic class module [K:H] (see Section ). The cyclotomic class can be given either by the cyclotomic class itself or by a representative, that is an integer coprime with [K:H].
The versions ended in NC does not check if (K,H) is a strongly Shoda pair of G and, in the four input data version, if C is either of generating q-cyclotomic class C module [K:H] or an integer coprime with [K:H].

ManSection.Description:
The versions with three input data computes the numerical information describing the Wedderburn component of the rational group algebra QG of a finite group G realized by a strongly Shoda pair (K,H) of G (see Section ).
The versions with four input data computes a pair [n,q] of positive integers with q a prime power describing the Wedderburn component of the semisimple finite group algebra FG realized by a strongly Shoda pair (K,H) of G and a generating q-cyclotomic class C module [K:H] as the n by n matrix algebra over GF(q) (see Section ).
The fourth input data can be given either as a cyclotomic class or as one of its representatives.
The versions ended in NC does not check if (K,H) is a strongly Shoda pair of G and in the four input data version if C is a generating q-cyclotomic class C module [K:H] or an integer coprime with [K:H].
